Award.AwardTitle: NSF 2026: What Works in Workshops – Evolving Short-format Training to Serve Life Sciences STEM Professionals in the 21st Century
Award.AbstractNarration: With support from the NSF 2026 Fund Program in the Office of Integrated Activities, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory DNA Learning Center in New York and Georgetown University Medical Center are holding a conference on improving the availability and quality of training for life science researchers, educators, and other STEM professionals (STEM workforce). Life science research is highly interdisciplinary and relies on rapid advances happening across its sub-disciplines as well in computing, statistics, engineering, and mathematics. However, university degrees often fail to keep up with the pace of change and as a result the life science STEM workforce is unprepared to use and teach cutting edge methods and technologies. To address these challenges, this workforce often relies on short-format training such as bootcamps and workshops to acquire or reinforce newly required skills. Short-format training has advantages, like topical focus and ease of access, but studies show it often does not result in long-term change or successful use of new methods. Disparities among the STEM workforce can increase when high-quality training is not accessible or inclusive. The 2.5-day conference is an initial step in implementing the NSF 2026 Idea Machine “Reinventing Scientific Talent” Idea and brings together national and international experts on training, education, and life science research to develop a blueprint and build community for the transformation of short-format training. Improving short-format training in the life sciences will promote a better-prepared, and more inclusive, STEM workforce for the 21st Century. <br/><br/>This conference explores challenges in applying established principles from education research and professional development, identifies research opportunities, and defines strengths and weaknesses in short-format training. The conference organizers (representing the largest life science short-format training programs world-wide) developed an outline of discussion topics, and a process for identifying participants and incorporating broad community input beyond the initial set of attendees. The output of the meeting includes relevant research questions, sets of lessons learned, and recommendations for supporting career-long learning that will be applicable in the life sciences and other STEM fields. Ultimately, these outputs form a blueprint for improvement that supports communities, organizations, and programs developing and delivering short-format training.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to improve short-format training (SFT) for STEM professionals throughout their careers. The intellectual merit of this project arises from findings that SFT often lacks effective teaching methods, and the scarcity of the ability for STEM professionals to acquire new skills, rather than a shortage of STEM professionals. There has been less effort to develop lifelong learning opportunities for STEM professionals compared to K-16 STEM education.

 

A conference was organized to explore how SFT can be improved to serve career-spanning learning needs for STEM professionals in life sciences and beyond. Recommendations were developed by an international group of experts in educational sciences and the experiences of large international life science SFT programs. The recommendations are aligned with "The Bicycle Principles," which prioritize evidenced-based teaching, inclusiveness, equity, scalability, sharing, and sustainability. The recommendations cover different SFT contexts and stakeholder groups and include actions for instructors, programs, organizations, and funders.

 

This work is fully described and contextualized on a website created specifically for the project results (www.bikeprinciples.org). Outputs from the project include a white paper, a preprint outlining the meeting and 14 recommendations, and an updatable roadmap with suggestions for how diverse stakeholders in SFT can implement each recommendation. This work will help STEM professionals recognize and address skills gaps throughout their careers, positioning them to pursue impactful science and achieve their personal career goals. The broader impacts of this work include a foundational framework for SFT programs to work towards improvement and implementation of recommendations. 

 

The Bicycle Principles and accompanying recommendations apply to any SFT instruction and may be especially useful in rapidly evolving and multidisciplinary fields such as artificial intelligence, genomics, and precision medicine. Improving SFT could also broaden participation in STEMM by preparing practitioners more equitably with transformative skills. This is especially important for members of the STEMM workforce who have several decades of productivity ahead, but who may not benefit from education reforms that predominantly focus on undergraduate STEMM.
